persuasion_strategies.description: Ethical persuasion frameworks based on psychology and value-driven selling

core_principles.integrity_first: Never manipulate—always serve the customer's genuine best interest

strategies.name: Social Proof
strategies.description: People follow the actions of others, especially those similar to them

application.how_to_use: Share specific success stories from similar businesses or industries
application.example: We recently helped a cleaning company just like yours increase their monthly bookings by 40% in 90 days. They were skeptical too, but the results spoke for themselves.

ethical_boundaries: Only share real, verifiable results
Don't exaggerate or cherry-pick outliers
Ensure examples are relevant to customer's situation

strategies.name: Scarcity & Urgency
strategies.description: People value things more when they perceive limited availability

application.how_to_use: Highlight genuine time-sensitive opportunities or limited capacity
application.example: We only take on 3 new clients per month to ensure quality. We have one spot left for June, and after that, you'd be looking at July or August.

ethical_boundaries: Only create urgency based on real constraints
Never use false scarcity or fake deadlines
Don't pressure—inform and let them decide

strategies.name: Reciprocity
strategies.description: People feel obligated to give back when they receive something of value

application.how_to_use: Provide genuine value upfront—free audit, insights, or consultation
application.example: I'd love to do a free 15-minute website audit for you. No strings attached—I'll show you exactly what's working, what's not, and what quick wins you could implement today.

ethical_boundaries: Give value without expectation of immediate return
Don't make the 'free' offer feel like a trap
Ensure the value is genuinely useful, not a sales pitch

strategies.name: Authority & Expertise
strategies.description: People trust and follow credible experts in a field

application.when_to_use: Customer needs confidence in your capability
application.how_to_use: Demonstrate deep knowledge through insights, not credentials
application.example: Based on your industry and target market, I'd recommend focusing on local SEO first, then retargeting ads. Here's why: [specific reasoning based on data].

ethical_boundaries: Earn authority through knowledge, not boasting
Admit what you don't know
Focus on customer's success, not your credentials

strategies.name: Commitment & Consistency
strategies.description: People want to act consistently with their stated beliefs and past actions

application.when_to_use: Customer has expressed goals or values
application.how_to_use: Align your solution with their stated priorities
application.example: You mentioned that customer experience is your top priority. That's exactly what this solution delivers—a seamless, professional experience that keeps clients coming back.

ethical_boundaries: Only align if there's genuine fit
Don't twist their words to fit your agenda
Help them stay true to their values

strategies.name: Liking & Rapport
strategies.description: People prefer to do business with those they like and relate to

application.how_to_use: Find common ground, show genuine interest, mirror communication style
application.example: I saw on your site that you're a family-owned business—so are we. We get what it's like to build something from the ground up and protect your reputation.

ethical_boundaries: Be genuinely interested, not fake
Don't manufacture false commonalities
Respect differences

strategies.name: Contrast Principle
strategies.description: People evaluate options relative to alternatives, not in isolation

application.how_to_use: Show the cost of inaction or inferior alternatives
application.example: You could try to piece this together yourself with freelancers—most people spend $5K+ and 6 months before giving up. Or we can deliver it in 30 days for $3K, fully managed.

ethical_boundaries: Use real comparisons, not straw men
Don't unfairly criticize competitors
Present options honestly

strategies.name: Loss Aversion
strategies.description: People are more motivated to avoid losses than to achieve equivalent gains

application.when_to_use: Customer is comfortable with status quo
application.how_to_use: Highlight what they're currently losing or missing out on
application.example: Right now, you're losing about 60% of your website visitors because there's no clear call-to-action. That's like leaving money on the table every single day.

ethical_boundaries: Only highlight real, quantifiable losses
Don't fear-monger or catastrophize
Balance with positive vision

strategies.name: Storytelling
strategies.description: People remember and connect with stories more than facts

application.when_to_use: Explaining complex concepts or building emotional connection
application.how_to_use: Share customer journey stories with clear before/after transformation
application.example: Let me tell you about Sarah, a wedding photographer who was drowning in admin work. She was spending 20 hours a week on emails and bookings instead of shooting. We automated her entire client flow, and now she's booking 3x more weddings with half the admin time.

ethical_boundaries: Tell true stories (with permission)
Don't embellish or fabricate
Make the customer the hero, not yourself

strategies.name: Future Pacing
strategies.description: Help people visualize and emotionally experience the desired outcome

application.when_to_use: Customer is interested but needs to see the vision
application.how_to_use: Paint a vivid picture of their future success
application.example: Imagine it's six months from now. You're getting 5-10 qualified leads per week from your website. Your calendar is full. You're turning down work because you're booked solid. That's not a fantasy—that's what this system delivers.

ethical_boundaries: Only promise what you can realistically deliver
Don't create unrealistic expectations
Ground vision in concrete steps

objection_handling_sequence: Social Proof (show how others overcame same concern)

never: Sell something that won't serve the customer
always: Admit when you're not the right fit
Measure success by customer outcomes, not just sales
